body: Apparently this is also described in https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/572#issuecomment-426213131

hi @dmarkhas : Can you also send me the list of env variables used. `MlflowClient` seems to be correctly instantiating `RestStore`. However, when looking up the run since you are not supplying any `--run_id` from command like for `mlflow run ....` command, I wonder if it picking up env variable `MLFLOW_RUN_ID`

Apparently `mlflow run` actually sets that environment variable by itself for some reason (which then follows the correct logic of trying to "resume" - but I don't think it should be setting it in the first place).

You are right that `mlflow run` will create a subprocess with active run ID sent with environment setting. However, a couple of things are not adding up to me. Maybe you can help answer those.

Your client side code shows run ID as `63e35b4f66164976b27f3d849c0fe72e` from the log your posted.

```
=== Running command 'source activate mlflow-3eee9bd7a0713cf80a17bc0a4d659bc9c549efac && python train.py 0.42 0.1' in run with ID '63e35b4f66164976b27f3d849c0fe72e' ===
```
`mlflow runs` call stack -- if `run_id` argument is not specified it will create a run using `MlflowClient` fluent API which will point to `RestStore` backed server and then resume with actually running the subcommand.

However, looking at your server side stack trace is looking for another run ID `6c72666f96ff4e0fbd7cb2002f074460`. That should not happen. Do you know if this is the right stack? Also does either of the runs exist in your server running remotely. If you could `cd mlruns` folder and see in the appropriate experiment.

I apologize, it was a copy-paste error, this is the correct stack trace from the server (with the matching ID):

The run does not exist on the server.

I experience the same issue using python 3.7.0 and mlflow 0.7.0. I use remote mlflow server (running in Docker) and then trying to invoke `mlflow run`... From my simple understanding it seems that `mlflow run` creates a new `RUN_ID`on the fly. A subsequent request to find it on the remote server fails because it does not exist here. ### Client side: ### `$ mlflow run . === Created directory /tmp/tmpxrufk7z9 for downloading remote URIs passed to arguments of type 'path' === === Running command 'source activate mlflow-5003dfa88d6c9061e9623d2074be952dd30f85f0 && python simple_mlflow.py gini 7' in run with ID '**591aa2b23550476ca3af1715e4d9da91**' === API request to http://osi5398:5000/api/2.0/preview/mlflow/runs/get failed with code 500 != 200, retrying up to 2 more times. 4edc44175ef3435ba15ac161b7a490fc meta.yaml 1aa362c53ab14188bfb824670e675616 ae1314bf8e2442b9a921d4c49a2b3a99 4b635d741d3345b7b7c0d13173324c1f e2c64a044f044bd69badd4ba32ffa34f

Facing the same issue. Any progress or workaround?
thanks

How are ya'll specifying the tracking URI? I'd recommend doing so by setting the `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI` environment variable (which will be propagated to the Python process launched to run your Python script) instead of calling `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://some-uri")` within your Python script.

Calling `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://some-uri")` within your Python script and then attempting to execute the script via `mlflow run` won't work unless you set the `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI` environment variable to the same value before invoking `mlflow run`, e.g. via `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI=http://some-uri mlflow run ...`. 

This is because (as @sonnehansen mentioned) `mlflow run` first creates a run against the currently-configured tracking URI (so by default, the ./mlruns directory on your local filesystem) and then attempts to load that run when `start_run` is called in your Python script - if the tracking URIs are different in the two cases, you may see the abovementioned errors.
Thank you @smurching  that solved the problem for me
I'm going to close this issue since @smurching seems to have provided a solution. Please feel free to reopen it if this is still occurring.

Ok I think https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/2649 is duplicate of this one. But is it really solved? I agry that @smurching solution is working but is this really the optimal behaviour? 

Seems to me that setting the uri in the script looks cleaner than setting mannualy an env variable.

Stumbled upon this problem with v1.8.0.

Is the behaviour @smurching mentioned the intended one? The solution feels like a workaround. 

It is not always possible to set the env var on the terminal you will run a project in, so it would be handy to be able to use `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://some-uri")`. 

Thank you.

I also have de same issue with version 1.8.0. I've tried both with MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI and mlflow.set_tracking_uri. 

When I use MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI, is not connecting to the server but just storing the runs in the project's mlruns project.

This issue is still here as of mlflow `1.13.1`. The problem I have is that if I specify the tracking URI in `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI` instead of `mlflow.set_tracking_uri` I am not able to dynamically load my dotenv environment. I have to make sure that in every single place `mlflow run` is run, the  `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI` is defined beforehand. Or the alternative is just to not run with `mlflow run` but `python -m ...`.
I've set TRACKING_URI in the code as mlflow.set_tracking_uri(my uri) but how can i add env variable  MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI during mlflow run?

In my case it was just a matter of moving the `mlflow.set_tracking_uri` above `mlflow.start_run()`

So I changed **from this**:
```
    with mlflow.start_run() as run:
        mlflow.set_tracking_uri('http://localhost:5000')
        log_param("param1", randint(0, 100))
```
**To this:**
```
    mlflow.set_tracking_uri('http://localhost:5000')
    with mlflow.start_run() as run:
        log_param("param1", randint(0, 100))
```
